attributes.title: Protocol for sex and gender considerations in low back pain clinical practice guidelines: a scoping review.

summary.value: Attached is a protocol for "Sex and gender considerations in low back pain clinical practice guidelines: a scoping review." This is a pre-registration of the protocol (dated March 18, 2020), prior to title and abstract screening.

data.name: Protocol for Sex and Gender Based Differences in LBP.pdf

extra.selectedFileName: Protocol for Sex and Gender Based Differences in LBP.pdf

attributes.title: Difficult Conversations
attributes.description: Examining support and barriers in discussing difficult topics - grief, miscarriage, cancer

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

other.value: We released the targets survey to 8 individuals for pilot testing, but did not analyse the responses.

sample.value:
For our study on ‘targets’, we aim to recruit 150 participants per group, for a total of 450 participants. 

For our study on ‘talkers’, we plan to recruit 250 participants.

analyses.value:
As our questions are predominately exploratory, we plan to use basic descriptive analyses to understand the frequencies and helpfulness of phrase use. We also will examine the list of phrases to determine if treating items as a scale or set of sub scales is appropriate. As we do not have expected subscales, this will be examined using EFA.

We will use age, ethnicity (coded as 1 = White, 0 = Other Ethnicity), and gender as potential covariates if they are significantly correlated with our variables of interest.

For our study on ‘targets’, we will explore the data utilizing primarily using ANOVA to examine whether situation is associated with differences in frequency (at the item level only) or helpfulness of phrases (both at the item level and at the aggregate level, if appropriate). 

For our individual difference measures, we will examine associations (correlations) with the level of frequency and helpfulness of phrases. For any variables that show a significant association with our outcomes of interest (frequency, helpfulness), we will include them as covariates in regression models to determine if group (that is, situation) predicts frequency of or helpfulness of phrases above and beyond individual differences (e.g., attachment insecurity, coping).

For our study on ‘talkers’, we plan to examine both within- and between-person differences in phrase use frequency and helpfulness. As participants in this study will be expected to answer on all situations, we will have nested data which makes multi-level modeling the most appropriate analysis choice. We will test both random intercept and random slopes models to determine which model best fits our data. We will use Hoffman & Stawski’s (2009) approach to parse within- and between-person effects in all multilevel models. Each variable that has both a between and within-person component will be person-centered and grand-mean centered to obtain a ‘truer’ estimate of within-person effects. All continuous variables that are strictly between-person (i.e., all individual difference measures) will be grand-mean centered. 

For our individual difference measures, we will again examine associations (correlations) with the aggregate level of frequency and helpfulness of phrases. For any variables that show a significant association with our outcomes of interest (frequency, helpfulness), we will include them in multilevel models to determine if group (that is, situation) predicts frequency of or helpfulness of phrases above and beyond individual differences (e.g., attachment insecurity, coping). We will center individual difference variables to examine both between-person (grand mean center) and within-person (group mean center) effects. 

We also will compare means of frequency (at the item level only) and helpfulness (both at the item level and at the aggregate level, if appropriate) between targets (coded as ‘1’) and talkers (coded as ‘0’). We will look at correlations between targets’ and talkers’ ratings of frequency and helpfulness.

outliers.value:
Our exclusion criteria for our study on targets will include any individuals who have not experienced one of our difficult situations (i.e., cancer, miscarriage, bereavement) within the past 2-5 years. As we are interested in conversations about the event, recency is important, so we will begin by recruiting people who have experienced an event in the last 2 years.  If individuals have experienced an event more than 2 years but less than 5 years ago, they may be invited back to participate in the study depending on whether we are able to recruit enough individuals who have experienced the event more recently.

For both studies, participants will be required to read and write in English fluently.

We will include an open-ended attention check item, which the primary investigator and research officer will both read. Responses that that are deemed as incomprehensible (indicating a lack of ‘real’ response) by both the primary investigator and research officer will be excluded from analyses.

dependent.value:
In the study on targets, our dependent variables include a list of 43topics/phrases that individuals may use when discussing a difficult situation or life event, which will include Frequency of Phrase Use and Perceptions of Helpfulness. Frequency is assessed on a 7-point scale ranging from “Never” to “All the Time”. Perceptions of helpfulness is rated on a 7-point scale from “Extremely Unhelpful” to “Extremely Helpful”. 

As the study is exploratory, we plan to determine if the items hold together as a scale, but also will be examining items individually.

In the study on talkers, we will use a subset of the topics/phrases from the target study. We will compile this subset by examining topics/phrases that targets identify as happening frequently (mean frequency ≥ 3). Items will be included in this subset if the individual item is viewed as very unhelpful (mean ≤ 3), very helpful (mean ≥ 5), or exhibits polarized responses of both very unhelpful and very helpful ratings (examined via standard deviations and histograms).

conditions.value:
Our main variable of interest in both studies will be the type of difficult situation. In the first study, we will have three groups of individuals: those who have experienced cancer; those who have experienced miscarriage; and those who have experienced the death of someone close to them. In the second study, all participants will answer questions about each difficult situation. 

To assess individual difference, we will use full scales of: compassion (Santa Clara Brief Compassion Scale, Hwang et al. 2008), attachment insecurity (ECR-S, Wei et al., 2007), personality (TIPI, Gosling, Rentfrow, & Swann, 2003), and basic psychological needs of autonomy and relatedness (Deci, & Ryan, 2000; Deci et al., 2001). 

We also included a measure of general perceived interpersonal social support, using 5 items from the appraisal subscale of the ISEL (Cohen, Mermelstein, Kamarck, & Hoberman, 1985). We retained four items: “There is no one that I feel comfortable talking to about intimate personal problems”; “I feel that there is no one I can share my most private worries and fears with”; “There really is no one who can give me an objective view of how I’m handling my problems”; “There is at least one person I know whose advice I really trust”). We slightly modified one additional item, to encompass more general support (changed to: “I have people I trust that can help me when I’m dealing with a difficult situation” from the original: “There are several people that I trust to help solve my problems”). 

Coping was captured using several complete subscales from the BRIEF COPE (Carver, 1997) that appeared most applicable to an interpersonal context. These subscales included: use of emotional support, use of instrumental support, behavioural disengagement, venting, positive reframing, and acceptance.  

All of the above items were modified from their original scaling to a 7-point scale if needed.

We also will collect age, ethnicity, and gender from all participants to describe our sample. Moreover, for targets, we will assess experience by asking how many ‘weak ties’ (“people you don’t know well”) participants have talked to about their situation, to examine as a potential control variable.

For talkers, we will gather information about whether they have experienced one of the difficult situations themselves and, if so, when it occurred. We will report the type of situation and when it occurred descriptively to better understand and make generalizations with our sample, but we will consider using the experience of a difficult situation as a control variable if it is significantly associated with our key variables.

hypothesis.value:
We are looking at conversations between someone experiencing a difficult situation (i.e., miscarriage, cancer, or grief), and a non-close other. We aim to examine how often specific topics or phrases are used and the perceived supportiveness of such topics/phrases  
This project is designed in two separate, but related, studies. First, we will collect data from ‘targets’ (individuals who have experienced a difficult situation), about how often people employ each topic/phrase when talking to them, and the extent to which each topic/phrase was helpful. Second, we will collect data from ‘talkers’ asking them to imagine what topics/phrases they would say to a person experiencing each situation, and how helpful they think each topic/phrase would be. In both studies, we will examine the extent to which use or perceived supportiveness of certain phrases varies based on individual differences.

The studies are exploratory, and thus we do not have set hypotheses or predictions.

attributes.title: Scarcity, abundance, and Financial Homo Ignorans in debt management
attributes.description: How scarcity, abundance, and financial ignorance affect debt management and information avoidance

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: The impact of scarcity, abundance, and financial ignorance on debt management and information avoidance.

other.value:
We will extend the models described with Equations 1, 2, and 5, by adding control variables, as well as exploring the potentially different effects of FHI across the conditions by adding interaction effects between conditions and FHI score.

We will extend the models described with Equations 3 and 4 by adding control variables, exploring the potentially different effects of FHI across the conditions by adding interaction effects between conditions and FHI score, as well as exploring the potentially different effects of information avoidance across the conditions by adding interaction effects between conditions and dummy for Information Avoidance.

We will also conduct logit regression for the model described in Equation 5.

sample.value: We will stop data collection when we reach 1000 participants. The sample size has been chosen based on power calculations, to be able to detect a small-to-medium sized effect with power 0.9 in all the statistical analysis described above.

analyses.value:
1) Tests of the impact of shocks and financial ignorance (as measured by the FHI scale) on debt-management behavior (RQ1 and RQ4):
=> we will average RAOD and DAA over rounds 1-5 and 6-10 and conduct within-subject t-tests before and after the shock
=> we will conduct t-tests for differences-in-differences that compare changes in average behavior between rounds 1-5 and 6-10 across conditions (both for RAOD and DAA)
=> we will conduct panel regressions with random effects (if data justifies it) and clustered standard errors (at the subject level) for rounds 1-10:
 
RAOD_it=b_0+b_1*PS_it+b_2*NS_it+b_3*FHI_i+b_4*Round_it+ε_it (Eq. 1)

DAA_it=b_0+b_1*PS_it+b_2*NS_it+b_3*FHI_i+b_4*Round_it+ε_it  (Eq. 2)

2) Tests of the impact of information avoidance on debt-management behavior (RQ2):
=> we will average RAOD and DAA over rounds 6-10 and 11-15 and conduct within-subject t-tests before and after revealing the information (for those subjects who decided to reveal the information)
=> we will conduct t-tests for differences-in-differences that compare changes in average behavior between rounds 6-10 and 11-15 across subjects who revealed the information vs who avoided the information (within conditions, both for RAOD and DAA)
=> we will conduct panel regressions with random effects (if data justifies it) and clustered standard errors (at the subject level) including rounds 6-15:

RAOD_it=b_0+b_1*PS_it+b_2*NS_it+b_3*FHI_i+b_4*InfoAvoidance_it+b_5*Round_it+ε_it (Eq. 3)

DAA_it=b_0+b_1*PS_it+b_2*NS_it+b_3*FHI_i+b_4*InfoAvoidance_it+b_5*Round_it+ε_it (Eq. 4)

3) Tests of the impact of shocks and financial ignorance (as measured by the FHI scale) on information avoidance (RQ3 and RQ4):
 => Chi-squared test investigating whether the proportion of individuals who avoid information differs across conditions
=> Linear probability model with robust standard errors:

InfoAvoidance_i=b_0+b_1*PS_i+b_2*NS_i+b_3*FHI_i+ε_i (Eq. 5)

All tests are two-sided. Regressions (OLS) include a constant.

outliers.value: For each test mentioned above we will include everyone that completed the study.

dependent.value:
Debt management:
(a) The ratio of savings allocated to pay off the debt with the highest interest rate (RAOD) 
(b) The ratio of savings allocated to pay off the smallest debt (DAA) 

Information avoidance:
(a)	Binary variable taking value 1 if subject did not reveal additional information and 0 otherwise.

Another relevant variable in our study is trait ignorance. We will collect information about trait ignorance using Financial Homo Ignorans scale (Barrafrem et al 2020) and use it as one of the explanatory variables.

Barrafrem, K., Västfjäll, D., and Tinghög, G., 2020. Financial Homo Ignorans: measuring vulnerability to behavioral biases in household finance. Working paper. DOI: 10.31234/osf.io/q43ca

conditions.value:
This is a between-subject design in which individuals are randomized into one of three conditions: control, positive shock, negative shock. All subjects will play debt management game adapted from Amar et al. (2011) for 15 rounds. Subjects will start game with six debts that vary in size and interest rates. In each round, subjects will have to decide how they want to allocate their ‘savings’ to each of the six debts.

We vary the amount of savings that subjects have every round between conditions: 

(a)	In control condition individuals receive £10 000 per round in all rounds (1-15)
(b)	In positive shock condition individuals receive £10 000 per round in rounds 1-5 and £18 000 per round in rounds 6-15 (i.e., they experience positive financial shock)
(c)	In negative shock condition individuals receive £10 000 per round in rounds 1-5 and £2 000 per round in rounds 6-15 (i.e., they experience negative financial shock)

After round 10 individuals will be presented with an option to freely reveal information about the accumulated interest charges. Those who reveal the information will also be provided with accumulated interest charges in the remaining rounds.
 
Amar, M., Ariely, D., Ayal, S., Cryder, C. E., and Rick, S. I., (2011). Winning the Battle but Losing the War: The Psychology of Debt Management. Journal of Marketing Research, 48(SPL), pp.38–S50.

hypothesis.value:
RQ1. How do negative and positive shocks affect debt management?
RQ2. How does information avoidance affect debt management?
RQ3. How do negative and positive shocks affect information avoidance?
RQ4. What is the role of trait ignorance (as measured by Financial Homo Ignorans scale) in debt management and information avoidance?

When it comes to debt management behavior, we will look at two outcome variables: i) the ratio of savings allocated to the debt with highest interest rate and, ii) the ratio of savings allocated to the smallest debt.

•	H1: We predict that people who experience positive shocks allocate less of their savings to the debt with the highest interest rate compared to people who do not experience any shock. In addition, people who experience positive shocks allocate more of their savings to the smallest debt compared to people who do not experience any shock. This is due to increased slack.
•	H2: We predict that people who experience negative shocks allocate less of their savings to the debt with the highest interest rate compared to people who do not experience any shock. In addition, people who experience negative shocks allocate more of their savings to the smallest debt compared to people who do not experience any shock. This is due to scarcity and tunneling.
•	H3: We predict that people who avoid additional information allocate less of their savings to the debt with the highest interest rate compared to people who reveal additional information. In addition, people who avoid additional information allocate more of their savings to the smallest debt compared to people who reveal additional information.
•	H4: We predict that individuals with higher trait ignorance will allocate less savings to the debt with the highest interest rate and more savings to the smallest debt.

We also form hypotheses related to how shocks affect information avoidance:
•	We predict that people in negative shock condition will be more likely to avoid information than people in control condition. In addition, people in positive shock condition will be less likely to avoid information than people in control condition. 
•	We predict that individuals with higher trait ignorance will be more likely to avoid information

attributes.title: Clinical prediction model for the diagnosis of asthma in children and young people in primary care
attributes.description:
This project aims to derive and validate a clinical prediction rule for the diagnosis of asthma in children and young people in primary care. Code lists will be used to create variables from anonymised routinely collected medical records.

The code lists deposited are lists of Read code (version 2) that were used to identify the presence of:
1) an asthma specific code
2) evidence of lung function or reversibility testing having been considered or completed

Both code lists are based on published work: Nissen F, Morales DR, Mullerova H, Smeeth L, Douglas IJ, Quint JK. Validation of asthma recording in the Clinical Practice Research Datalink (CPRD). BMJ open. 2017 Aug 1;7(8):e017474 (2017) http://dx.doi.org/10.1136/bmjopen-2017-017474 

1) The asthma specific code list is available under a CC BY 3.0 License. Nissen, F and Quint, JK (2017). Clinical Code List - Specific Asthma Codes. [Data Collection]. London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine, London, United Kingdom. https://doi.org/10.17037/DATA.210. It was modified for the current project by converting from Medcode to Read code.

2) Nissen, F and Quint, JK (2017) used a list of Read codes to identify reversibility. The list was expanded upon (over 150 additional codes) to incorporate evidence of lung function or reversibility testing having been considered or conducted. 

I am indebted to Nissen, F and Quint, JK for allowing me access to their code lists.

summary.value:
This project aims to derive and validate a clinical prediction model for the diagnosis of children and young people in primary care. The study protocol has been submitted to a journal. 

The uploaded files are code lists (described in the protocol) that will be used to construct variables to be included in the prediction modelling process.
The lists comprise Read codes (version 2) and describe:
1) Asthma specific codes
2) Codes relating to lung function or reversibility testing having been considered or conducted.

Both code lists are based on published work: Nissen F, Morales DR, Mullerova H, Smeeth L, Douglas IJ, Quint JK. Validation of asthma recording in the Clinical Practice Research Datalink (CPRD). BMJ open. 2017 Aug 1;7(8):e017474 (2017) http://dx.doi.org/10.1136/bmjopen-2017-017474

attributes.title: Manipulation under anaesthesia versus conservative treatment for frozen shoulder contracture syndrome: a systematic review
attributes.description: Systematic review on efficacy of MUA in FSCS

q1.value: Manipulation under anaesthesia versus conservative treatment for frozen shoulder contracture syndrome: a systematic review.

q2.value: Mattia Salomon, Tiziano Innocenti, Fabrizio Brindisino, Silvia Giagio, Chiara Pastore, Mauro Di Bari

q3.value: Frozen shoulder is a poorly understood condition that typically involves substantial pain, movement restriction, and considerable morbidity. Although function improves overtime, full and pain free range, may not be restored in everyone. Manipulation under anaesthesia (MUA) is believed to be the most widely used non-conservative treatment option for these refractory cases of frozen shoulders. The aim of the study is to compare the efficacy between MUA and conservative treatment in patient affected by frozen shoulder contracture syndrome.

q4.value: The aim of the systematic review is to obtain a better understanding of the role of manipulation under anesthesia in the treatment of frozen shoulder and to evaluate the effectiveness of MUA compared to other conservative therapeutic options described in current literature in patient affected by frozen shoulder contracture syndrome.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The systematic review was organized and reported based on the Preferred Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) statement. 
A research on 5 scientific database (MEDLINE, Cochrane Library CENTRAL, PEDro, Embase and Scopus) has been conducted. In addition, a manual search was performed on the reference lists of included articles and other grey literature sources (eg. Google Scholar).
Only randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and controlled, non-randomized studies of intervention will be included (NRSI). Partecipants and population will be selected by specified inclusion and exclusion criteria. Comparator will allow the following conservative strategies: physiotherapy, manual therapy, stretching, injections, exercise therapy.
Main outcome(s) of the review: measures of Pain, Range of Motion, function, quality of life.
Additional outcome(s): of the review: measures of return to work, muscle strength, patient (and clinician) satisfaction, perceived quality of treatment, adverse events.
Two reviewers blinded will read titles, abstracts and full texts to identify articles of interest with Rayyan QCRI software for systematic reviews.
Consensus between the two reviewers is necessary to include the studies in the review. A third independent reviewer will be consulted for a final decision if a consensus is not achieved by the first two initial reviewers.
Data and results of the included studies will be extracted using a standardized form collecting patient's characteristics, selection criteria, type of interventions, follow-up periods, outcome measures and results.
The internal validity of the included studies will be assessed with the Cochrane risk-of-bias tool for randomized studies and ROBINS-I for non-randomized studies.
In our study, we will synthesize the data using a random-effect method, with standardized mean differences (SMD) for continuous outcomes and risk ratios (RR) for dichotomus outcomes.
We will also calculate 95% confidence intervals and two-sided P values for each indicator. χ2 test and the I² statistic will be used to assess the heterogeneity among studies. An I² value greater than 60% will be considered as substantial heterogeneity. Sensitivity analyses based on study quality will be conducted. If a substantial heterogeneity will be found, a stratified meta-analysis will be conducted according to various factors, such as study populations (eg. diabetic patients). We will also assess evidence of publication bias with funnel plots methods.
All analyses would be performed using Review Manager Version 5.3 software for statistical analysis.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
The systematic review was organized and reported based on the Preferred Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) statement. 
A research on 5 scientific database (MEDLINE, Cochrane Library CENTRAL, PEDro, Embase and Scopus) has been conducted. In addition, a manual search was performed on the reference lists of included articles and other grey literature sources (eg. Google Scholar).

INCLUSION CRITERIA: 
- only randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and controlled, non-randomized studies of intervention will be included (NRSI); 
- humans, adult population (male and female) with target condition (frozen shoulder contracture syndrome; 
- articled in English, German or Italian.

EXCLUSION CRITERIA: 
- other type of studies; 
- patients with fractures, dislocation (acute or recurrent), complete rotator cuff tears, infections, cancer conditions, systemic disease (except for diabetes)
- other languages.


INTERVENTION: manipulation under anaesthesia (MUA).
COMPARATOR: conservative strategies (physiotherapy, manual therapy, stretching, injections, exercise therapy).

Main outcome(s) of the review: measures of Pain, Range of Motion, function, quality of life.
Additional outcome(s): of the review: measures of return to work, muscle strength, patient (and clinician) satisfaction, perceived quality of treatment, adverse events.

Two reviewers blinded will read titles, abstracts and full texts to identify articles of interest with Rayyan QCRI software for systematic reviews.
Consensus between the two reviewers is necessary to include the studies in the review. A third independent reviewer will be consulted for a final decision if a consensus is not achieved by the first two initial reviewers.
Data and results of the included studies will be extracted using a standardized form collecting patient's characteristics, selection criteria, type of interventions, follow-up periods, outcome measures and results.

A third independent reviewer will be consulted for a final decision if a consensus is not achieved by the first two initial reviewers. Data and results of the included studies will be extracted using a standardized form collecting patient's characteristics, selection criteria, type of interventions, follow-up periods, outcome measures and results.

RISK OF BIAS QUALITY ASSESSMENT: the internal validity of the included studies will be assessed with the Cochrane risk-of-bias tool for randomized studies and ROBINS-I for non-randomized studies.

DATA SYNTHESIS: in our study, we will synthesize the data using a random-effect method, with standardized mean differences (SMD) for continuous outcomes and risk ratios (RR) for dichotomus outcomes.
We will also calculate 95% confidence intervals and two-sided P values for each indicator. χ2 test and the I² statistic will be used to assess the heterogeneity among studies. An I² value greater than 60% will be considered as substantial heterogeneity. Sensitivity analyses based on study quality will be conducted. If a substantial heterogeneity will be found, a stratified meta-analysis will be conducted according to various factors, such as study populations (eg. diabetic patients). We will also assess evidence of publication bias with funnel plots methods.
All analyses would be performed using Review Manager Version 5.3 software

summary.value:
Study preregistration


Introduction

The analyses described below are going to be part of a dissertation based on the study ”The making of an expert detective: the role of experience in English and Norwegian police officers’ investigative decision- making” by Ivar Fahsing and Karl Ask (2016). In that study the authors compared the expertise of experienced and novice police officers in England and Norway. In this dissertation a comparison will be made between experienced and novice police officers in England and four other countries combined (Iceland, Norway, the Netherlands and Denmark). For additional information see the original study by Fahsing and Ask (2016).  

Participants / Data

Data from England (n = 61) and Norway (n = 63) comes from the original study. Data from Denmark (n = 62), Iceland (n = 57) and the Netherlands (n = 59) has been gathered using the same method described in the original study. 

Dependent measures

Participants were presented with two crime scenarios based on actual missing-person cases in written form. They were then asked to generate as many relevant hypotheses and investigative actions as they could regarding the events of the scenarios. The participants’ answers were then compared to a gold standard consisting of hypotheses and investigative actions generated by an international panel of 30 senior homicide detectives. The dependent measures are the number of generated investigative hypotheses and actions also found in the gold standard. 

Hypothesis

H1: Experienced participants will outperform novices to a greater extent in the English sample, compared with the combined Norwegian, Icelandic, Danish and Dutch samples, in terms of the amount of generated gold-standard investigative hypotheses and actions.

Data analysis plan

Hypothesis testing:

The primary dependent variables are the amount of generated gold-standard investigative hypotheses and actions.

A factorial 2 (experience: novice vs. experienced) × 5 (country: England vs. Norway vs. Iceland vs. the Netherlands vs. Denmark) ANOVA will be used to compare the effects of experience on the ability to generate investigative hypotheses and actions in the different countries. 

The primary test of the study's hypothesis will be an interaction contrast comparing the effect of experience in the English sample to the effect of experience in the combined Norwegian, Icelandic, Dutch and Danish samples.  

The hypothesis will be regarded as confirmed if the interaction contrast is statistically significant at the .05 level and the group means differ in the predicted direction. 

Exploratory analysis:

Simple effects analysis will be used to study effects of experience within each country. 

References

Fahsing, I. & Ask, K. (2016) The making of an expert detective: The role of experience in English and Norwegian police officers’ investigative decision-making. Psychology, Crime & Law, 22(3), 203-223. doi: 10.1080/1068316X.2015.1077249

Study preregistration


Introduction

In that study the authors compared the expertise of experienced and novice police officers in England and Norway. In this dissertation a comparison will be made between experienced and novice police officers in England and four other countries combined (Iceland, Norway, the Netherlands and Denmark). Data from England (n = 61) and Norway (n = 63) comes from the original study. Data from Denmark (n = 62), Iceland (n = 57) and the Netherlands (n = 59) has been gathered using the same method described in the original study.

attributes.title: PROSPERO and PRISMA-P
attributes.description: Methodological study to assess the extent to which the contents of PROSPERO records meet the systematic review protocol reporting items in PRISMA-P

q1.value: An assessment of the extent to which the contents of PROSPERO records meet the systematic review protocol reporting items in PRISMA-P: study protocol

q2.value: Alison Booth, Sophie James, Sarah Cockayne, Andrew Mott, Samantha Gascoyne, Alex Mitchell

q3.value: Systematic review details registered in PROSPERO are frequently the only source of a priori methods available to readers (e.g. peer reviewers, clinicians) of completed reviews. This study will compare the information reported in registrations with reporting guidelines for systematic review protocols (PRISMA-P) to assess the completeness of information available.

q4.value: This study will investigate the extent to which records in PROSPERO comply with each of the items for reporting of protocols set out in the PRISMA-P guidelines, when no protocol or other information is available.  We will explore whether country, number of authors, funding, topic, and planned meta-analysis have any association with the completeness or otherwise of reporting specific items.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

q7.value: In the dual assessment, researchers will be blinded to each other's scoring.

question.value: This is a methodological study comparing a random sample of protocol registration records with published reporting criteria.

data.name: PROSPERO vs PRISMA P_Study protocol v1.0 15 March 2020.pdf

extra.selectedFileName: PROSPERO vs PRISMA P_Study protocol v1.0 15 March 2020.pdf

data.name: Appendix 1 of P P_P study v1.0 15 March 2020.pdf

extra.selectedFileName: Appendix 1 of P P_P study v1.0 15 March 2020.pdf

q9.value:
Randomisation will not be used in this study. A 20% random sample will be drawn from all eligible records, using simple random sampling without replacement. This will be done using the sample function in the base functionality of R.

Citation:  R Core Team (2019). R: A language and environment for statistical computing. R Foundation for Statistical Computing, Vienna, Austria. URL  https://www.R-project.org/.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
The sample records will be obtained from the full dataset of PROSPERO records in accordance with the following eligibility criteria

Inclusion criteria
•	Registration published in PROSPERO on or between 1 January 2018 and 31 December 2018
•	Systematic review of a health care intervention (as self-defined by authors in PROSPERO)
•	Single registration record (i.e. no amendments have been made)
•	PROSPERO record does not state there is a peer reviewed published protocol or provide information about or access to a protocol 

Exclusion criteria
•	Cochrane reviews
•	Reviews of animal studies
•	Non-intervention reviews as identified in PROSPERO i.e. Diagnostic accuracy, Prognostic factors, Prevention, Epidemiological reviews relevant to health and social care, Public health, Service delivery in health and social care, Methodological
•	Reviews of reviews
•	Synthesis of qualitative studies
•	Provides any files, question response, or reference to a protocol

q13.value: A 20% random sample will be drawn from all eligible records in a full PROSPERO registration dataset. The PROSPERO dataset contains 5,313 records for reviews of interventions first accepted in 2018 (excluding Cochrane and reviews of animal studies). Applying the other study inclusion/ exclusion criteria results in 2,194 eligible registration records. We will assess the reporting of information in the random sample of 439 (20%) of these records.

q14.value: The eligibiity criteria focus selection of records for inclusion on the type of systematic review that PROSPERO and PRISMA-P are specifically designed for. The choice of 20% of eligible records is a pragmatic choice to balance assessment of a representative sample with resources for this unfunded study.

question.value:
The primary outcome for this study will be the compliance between registration records and PRISMA-P reporting items. Each of the 21 items will carry a score of 1 where reporting is complete, making the maximum possible score 21.

We will also report on the number of elements within PRISMA-P items assessed as completely reported in PROSPERO. 

Demographic data will be reported, to include: month of registration, funding, country, number of authors, topic of review, stage of review, meta-analysis planned, using the following definitions:

Funding: Field 12. Funding sources/sponsors in PROSPERO is a single free text field which prohibits consistent differentiation between funder/funding and sponsor/sponsorship for the full 2018 dataset. We will therefore categorise the information provided as either ‘no listed funder or sponsor’ or ‘listed sponsor or funder’.

Topic of review: will be reported as self-defined by authors in PROSPERO. The PROSPERO topic of review options are based on the Health Research Classification system (https://hrcsonline.net/health-categories/). Additional codes are included in PROSPERO to accommodate the broad nature of the inclusion criteria.

Stage of review: authors are required to indicate the stage of their review at the time of registration in a matrix as below. We will define stage of review as the furthest point in the review process indicated by authors of records. 

Meta-analysis planned: assessor responses to PRISMA-P item 15b, sub-question about whether a meta-analysis is planned will be used.

Options for assessment decisions will be: Yes (information provided as per PRISMA-P requirements); No (some or all information not provided); and, where relevant, Not applicable/None Stated. Where PRISMA-P items specify more than one piece of information, the individual elements will be listed separately and scored as above. 

Where the required information is present (Yes) the score for an item will be 1; if the information is not reported (No) the score for the item will be 0. Where an item is sub-divided, scoring will be assigned on the basis that if any of the responses are No the overall score for the item will be 0; if all the responses to the elements are Yes, the item score is 1. The maximum possible overall score will be 21. The scores for the individual elements of items will  be presented to demonstrate where registration information partially meets the PRISMA-P requirements and whether there are any persistent gaps in reporting.

We will prepare and present descriptive statistics only: tables, graphs and figures will be used where appropriate. These will cover, selection of study sample, primary outcome of overall compliance score, breakdown of elements score, scores for the variables identified above. 
For each individual item (and sub item), we will present the number and percentage to score 1. 
For the overall total score for records we will present the mean, standard deviation, median, and inter-quartile range.

registration_responses.q14: The eligibiity criteria focus selection of records for inclusion on the type of systematic review that PROSPERO and PRISMA-P are specifically designed for. The choice of 20% of eligible records is a pragmatic choice to balance assessment of a representative sample with resources for this unfunded study.
registration_responses.q8.question: This is a methodological study comparing a random sample of protocol registration records with published reporting criteria.

q8.uploader.file_name: PROSPERO vs PRISMA P_Study protocol v1.0 15 March 2020.pdf
Appendix 1 of P P_P study v1.0 15 March 2020.pdf

registration_responses.q12.question:
The sample records will be obtained from the full dataset of PROSPERO records in accordance with the following eligibility criteria

Inclusion criteria
•	Registration published in PROSPERO on or between 1 January 2018 and 31 December 2018
•	Systematic review of a health care intervention (as self-defined by authors in PROSPERO)
•	Single registration record (i.e. no amendments have been made)
•	PROSPERO record does not state there is a peer reviewed published protocol or provide information about or access to a protocol 

Exclusion criteria
•	Cochrane reviews
•	Reviews of animal studies
•	Non-intervention reviews as identified in PROSPERO i.e. Diagnostic accuracy, Prognostic factors, Prevention, Epidemiological reviews relevant to health and social care, Public health, Service delivery in health and social care, Methodological
•	Reviews of reviews
•	Synthesis of qualitative studies
•	Provides any files, question response, or reference to a protocol
registration_responses.q16.question: Not applicable.
registration_responses.q17.question:
The primary outcome for this study will be the compliance between registration records and PRISMA-P reporting items. Each of the 21 items will carry a score of 1 where reporting is complete, making the maximum possible score 21.

We will also report on the number of elements within PRISMA-P items assessed as completely reported in PROSPERO. 

Demographic data will be reported, to include: month of registration, funding, country, number of authors, topic of review, stage of review, meta-analysis planned, using the following definitions:

Funding: Field 12. Funding sources/sponsors in PROSPERO is a single free text field which prohibits consistent differentiation between funder/funding and sponsor/sponsorship for the full 2018 dataset. We will therefore categorise the information provided as either ‘no listed funder or sponsor’ or ‘listed sponsor or funder’.

Topic of review: will be reported as self-defined by authors in PROSPERO. The PROSPERO topic of review options are based on the Health Research Classification system (https://hrcsonline.net/health-categories/). Additional codes are included in PROSPERO to accommodate the broad nature of the inclusion criteria.

Stage of review: authors are required to indicate the stage of their review at the time of registration in a matrix as below. We will define stage of review as the furthest point in the review process indicated by authors of records. 

Meta-analysis planned: assessor responses to PRISMA-P item 15b, sub-question about whether a meta-analysis is planned will be used.
registration_responses.q18.question:
Options for assessment decisions will be: Yes (information provided as per PRISMA-P requirements); No (some or all information not provided); and, where relevant, Not applicable/None Stated. Where PRISMA-P items specify more than one piece of information, the individual elements will be listed separately and scored as above. 

Where the required information is present (Yes) the score for an item will be 1; if the information is not reported (No) the score for the item will be 0. Where an item is sub-divided, scoring will be assigned on the basis that if any of the responses are No the overall score for the item will be 0; if all the responses to the elements are Yes, the item score is 1. The maximum possible overall score will be 21. The scores for the individual elements of items will  be presented to demonstrate where registration information partially meets the PRISMA-P requirements and whether there are any persistent gaps in reporting.
registration_responses.q19.question:
We will prepare and present descriptive statistics only: tables, graphs and figures will be used where appropriate. These will cover, selection of study sample, primary outcome of overall compliance score, breakdown of elements score, scores for the variables identified above. 
For each individual item (and sub item), we will present the number and percentage to score 1. 
For the overall total score for records we will present the mean, standard deviation, median, and inter-quartile range.

attributes.title: EEGLAB datasets for study of event-related potentials during categorization of  emotionally-charged and neutral images with distinct second-order features in carriers of polymorphisms of the COMT, HTR2A, BDNF genes
attributes.description: Datasets of this project are ERP-recordings which were made during the study aimed to discover the association between parameters of the event-related potentials and categorization of images of visual scenes with distinct second-order features, both emotionally-charged and neutral, in carriers of polymorphisms of the COMT, HTR2A, BDNF genes

summary.value: Datasets of this project are ERP-recordings which were made during the study aimed to discover the association between parameters of the event-related potentials and categorization of images of visual scenes with distinct second-order features, both emotionally-charged and neutral, in carriers of polymorphisms of the COMT, HTR2A, BDNF genes. Recordings divided by condition 1,2 and 3, which are respectively negative, neutral and positive emotional estimation of emotionally-charged and neutral visual stimuli, that were presented in our experiment. There are also three variables for the subject of this data - genotypes of COMT, BDNF, HTR2A genes, via them one can divide the subjects into number of groups. Recordings are datasets for work in EEGLAB, special MATLAB/OCTAVE toolbox for processing electrophysiological data. Each dataset consists of two files with .set and .fdt formats according to the data structure in the EEGLAB. For correct work, it is necessary that both types of files are in the same directory. The database contains 102 EEG recordings, 34 for each condition, 204 files in total. The recordings themselves are a set of epochs for averaging ERPs. Each file contains a different number of epochs, since bad epochs with artifacts have already been cleaned.

registration_responses.summary: Datasets of this project are ERP-recordings which were made during the study aimed to discover the association between parameters of the event-related potentials and categorization of images of visual scenes with distinct second-order features, both emotionally-charged and neutral, in carriers of polymorphisms of the COMT, HTR2A, BDNF genes. Recordings divided by condition 1,2 and 3, which are respectively negative, neutral and positive emotional estimation of emotionally-charged and neutral visual stimuli, that were presented in our experiment. There are also three variables for the subject of this data - genotypes of COMT, BDNF, HTR2A genes, via them one can divide the subjects into number of groups. Recordings are datasets for work in EEGLAB, special MATLAB/OCTAVE toolbox for processing electrophysiological data. Each dataset consists of two files with .set and .fdt formats according to the data structure in the EEGLAB. For correct work, it is necessary that both types of files are in the same directory. The database contains 102 EEG recordings, 34 for each condition, 204 files in total. The recordings themselves are a set of epochs for averaging ERPs. Each file contains a different number of epochs, since bad epochs with artifacts have already been cleaned.
